newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli CPI-linked bonds end rally.
newsitem.headline: Israeli CPI-linked bonds end rally.

text.p: Israeli CPI-linked bonds closed lower on Tuesday, ending an eight-session rally, traders said.
* Unlinked government bonds (Gilon -- issued for four years): +0.05 pct to 103.71
* Bank of Israel short-term Makam bills: +0.05 pct at 102.9
Volume was low at 134 million shekels.
"CPI-linked bonds made a very big move since the beginning of last week and they need to take a rest before they can continue thier rise," said Ron Weisberg at I.B.I. Investment House.
Weisberg added that inflation-linked bonds continued to show strength with short bonds rising and medium-term bonds declining mildly.

"Unlinked bonds and Makams were today's main gainers but activity was relatively low. I believe that CPI-linked bonds will continue to rise with yields on long bonds falling from 4.1 percent to less than four percent," said a trader at United Mizrahi Bank.

Traders noted that dollar-linked bonds closed slightly lower after the shekel rose mildly against the dollar. In the local market, the representative rate for the dollar was fixed at 3.3680 shekels against 3.3700 shekels on Monday.
Note: Makams are zero-coupon unlinked certificates with durations of three months to one year. The Bank of Israel issues Makams to absorb liquidity.
